Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PVV-RF71-DY2V-D1MJ-00000-00Amazon, Google Group Asks Regulators to Keep Their Hands Off AI2017-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:35ZLexisNexisAmazon, Google Group Asks Regulators to Keep Their Hands Off AIBloomberg

(Bloomberg) -- A lobbying group representing top artificial-intelligence companies including Amazon.com Inc., Facebook Inc. and Google issued a warning to lawmakers on Tuesday: hands off our algorithms.

The Information Technology Industry Council released “AI Principles," spelling out how governments should approach AI, a technology that lets computers learn by themselves, and what the industry sees as its own responsibilities.



Government should “use caution before adopting new laws, regulations or taxes that may inadvertently or unnecessarily impede the responsible development and use of AI," according to an executive summary of the principles.

Big tech companies, and their software, are coming under more scrutiny in the wake of news that Russian-sponsored accounts used social networks to spread discord and try to influence the outcome of the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Algorithms designed by Facebook, Twitter Inc. and Google have also been criticized for increasing political polarization by giving people the type of news they already agree with, creating so-called “filter bubbles."

“We are at the early stages of the commercialization of AI," ITI President Dean Garfield said. “Given the reach of AI, we think it’s critical that society, governments, and the technology sector work together to begin to solve some of the most complex issues." ITI presented the principles Tuesday at a conference in Washington hosted by a unit of Bloomberg LP, the parent company of Bloomberg News.

ITI stressed that governments shouldn’t ask companies to share or expose the code behind their AI systems. That touches on a key issue for the companies, which don’t want to have to explain the workings of AI systems that produce results their creators sometimes don’t fully understand themselves. In Europe, regulators have told tech companies they don’t mind how algorithms work, as long as they don’t break the law.

Facebook’s head of security, Alex Stamos, took to Twitter earlier this month to warn that the issue of fake news on social networks was more complicated than it’s often made out to be and trying to interfere with algorithms could have unintended consequences.

AI is one of the hottest fields of technological research, with Alphabet Inc.’s Google, Amazon, Facebook and Chinese internet giants like Baidu Inc. racing to develop computer programs that learn on their own. ITI estimates AI will add at least $7 trillion to the global economy by 2025.

Despite the promise, criticisms range from Elon Musk’s fears of AI being an existential threat to humanity to the problem of mostly male scientists and developers injecting their own biases into AI.

Tech companies have a responsibility to make sure the data and tools they use to develop AI mitigate bias, Garfield said, describing the principles as a commitment from industry to work on this problem.

The principles also acknowledge concerns that AI will disrupt labor markets, pushing more people out of work as computers learn to do tasks better than humans. Education, private-public partnerships and building AI programs that help people do their jobs should be priorities, the ITI report said.

"Any time you are driving innovation in a society that is transformative and as a result potentially uncomfortable, there are going to be points of tension," Garfield said. "The thing that we are trying to do is to make sure we’re at the center of trying to identify those points of tension and trying to resolve them. The bottom line is we hear the concerns that are being raised."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5HGX-RD11-JB4M-V0HH-00000-00Amazon has a new drone delivery video. Here are 8 details worth noting.2015-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:35ZLexisNexisAmazon has a new drone delivery video. Here are 8 details worth noting.Matt McFarland

Almost exactly two years after first announcing its plans to deliver packages with a drone, Amazon revealed a new prototype of one of its delivery drones. Here are some interesting revelations:

1. Amazon built a "hybrid" drone

Amazon's prototype is an octocopter - meaning it has eight propellers and can take off and land vertically, like a helicopter. But the design also includes wings and a "pusher motor" so that it can transition from helicopter takeoffs to the energy-efficient flight of a plane at altitude. A pure octocopter wouldn't be capable of a range of 15 miles, like this prototype.

At altitude, only the pusher motor - - is in motion. The eight other propellers reactivate once the drone is about to land and needs to make a vertical descent into a yard.

2. Backyards will be key for Amazon Prime Air

The video shows the drone switching into "landing mode" and descending onto a "delivery zone" in the customer's backyard. The drone releases the package onto what looks like a sheet of plastic with an Amazon logo. The larger the yard and the less tree cover, the easier the landing will be.

3. Amazon sticks with a different approach than Google

Just like its first drone video, the Amazon drone lands to drop off a package. This is a different tactic than what rival Google has demonstrated , in which its hovering drone releases a package that floats to the ground.

Amazon will need to be certain its drone can land in a backyard without any mishaps involving a family pet, kids, stray sports equipment, a new birdbath or whatever else might be in a yard.

4. What about safety?

Amazon says its drone has "sophisticated 'sense and avoid' technology," which will be essential for those backyard landings. Everyone from big tech companies such as Amazon to start-ups is developing this technology, so that drones can identify obstacles and automatically avoid them. For example, with sense and avoid, a drone would realize a dog had strayed into its landing zone, and not land until the coast was clear.

Because this prototype has nine propellers it will still function even if multiple motors fail.

5. It'll likely be a lot faster than your local delivery truck

One section of the video, which Amazon notes is actual flight footage, shows the drone flying between 55-58 mph. That speed will come in handy if Amazon is going to deliver on its promise of getting packages to customers in 30 minutes.

6. It's a big drone

Amazon isn't saying how much this prototype weighs, only that its drones weigh less than 55 pounds. And it's not sharing the prototype's wingspan. If you look at the photo below and remember that blue box is actually a shoe box, it's obvious the drone is far larger than the consumer drones we see most frequently, such as the DJI Phantom and Parrot Bebop.

A larger drone means Amazon can carry larger packages. Larger drones are generally heavier, which increases risk in the event of the crash. At the same time, all that size creates space for the nine propellers - and a drone with nine motors has more back-up propellers that a drone with four propellers, which improves safety.

7. Remember, it's just a prototype.

Don't expect an exact replica of this drone to eventually land in your backyard. Amazon says it has more than a dozen prototypes in its research and development labs, and that the look of characteristics will continue to evolve. Amazon's prototype has changed quite a bit in two years, who knows what it'll look like in 2017.

8. Amazon chose a British broadcaster for voiceover purposes

Former Top Gear host Jeremy Clarkson - who is developing a show for Amazon - does the honors. Amazon has taken its testing overseas given its frustration with the slog toward commercial drone regulation in the United States. Amazon says it will launch Prime Air once it has regulatory support. Don't be surprised if it launches first outside the United States.

Amazon says the prototype can operate safely "beyond line of sight" to distances of 10 miles or more. That means outside the view of the person responsible for controlling it. However the FAA's proposed commercial drone rules, released in February, require drones to fly where the drone's pilot can see it. While U.S. drones may eventually be able to fly out of sight , the process isn't moving as fast as Amazon would like.

Related: Amazon's plans for how drones can fly safely over U.S. skies

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WP8-HJ11-F0R9-T4FW-00000-00Amazon Has Too Much Power. Take It Back.2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:35ZLexisNexisAmazon Has Too Much Power. Take It Back.

Covid-19 has created strange bedfellows. Six months ago, a labor leader and an Amazon vice president would have been on opposite sides in discussing the future of work at Big Tech in general and Amazon in particular. Then on May 1, one of us, Tim, walked away from a senior role at Amazon Web Services, and potentially millions in compensation, in protest over the firing of workers who spoke out about conditions in the companys warehouses.

During the pandemic, weve seen Big Tech share prices and revenue rocket, while some of Amazons warehouse workers say they fear coming to work and catching the coronavirus. The companys decision to fire the activists who demanded safer jobs is unacceptable.

Both of us now agree: Amazon and the rest of Big Tech must change. And that includes allowing its workers to unionize.

Were not alone in wanting accountability from these companies: Jeff Bezos and the heads of Facebook, Google and Apple will appear before the House judiciarys antitrust subcommittee today.

The coronavirus has killed over half a million people worldwide and pushed global unemployment to rates not seen since the Great Depression. Shared sacrifice is called for, yet the burden has been far from even. Since mid-March, when quarantined shoppers turned to Amazons vast retail platform, its shareholder value increased by nearly $500 billion, to more than $1.4 trillion. Stock market shares are owned disproportionately by the richest people in society, and by Mr. Bezos in particular ; his lead over the other richest people on earth has increased markedly.

This wealth is not shared with the workers who help create it. The temporary Covid-19-related hourly raise was rolled back in June , but the order flow remains high , making the already stressful work of those who sort, package and deliver Amazon goods even worse.

We Work in an Amazon Warehouse. We Didnt Sign Up to Be Heroes.

Thanks for the flattering commercials, but were about to lose our hazard pay.

My typical morning, my cat usually jumps on my face. Then my alarm goes off about 4 oclock. I cry for about a good three minutes. Usually during the day, I am numb. I am on autopilot. So I give myself that three minutes to let everything out. So that way I dont you know, have a breakdown. I grocery shop for thousands, maybe millions of people a day. I dont know. Were the back, legs, arms. We are the body of Amazon. We dont need your thank you commercials. We need better protections and to be paid what we deserve. Amazon has reportedly confirmed its going to stop paying its warehouse workers that extra $2 an hour in coronavirus hazard pay. Amazons unlimited unpaid-leave policy ended on May 1. That means if you have coronavirus, you are expected to still show up to work even after two weeks have passed. I have lupus nephritis, which means my immune system is weak. So if I even get the mild condition of just getting corona, I would end up in critical condition because thats how weak my body is. Theyre still getting cases every other day or every other week, and not just our warehouse on Staten Island but across the United States. Im home now scared to go to work. They ended the UPT policy. My leave of absence ended May 9. I requested a new leave, and Amazon denied it. This is my source of income for the past two years. I dont want to give up the job, but in this pandemic, theyre making me choose between my life or a customers order. Amazon is acting like the pandemic is over and everything is back to normal. They call us essential. They call us heroes. But Im just going to say it. We are expendable. You have 30 million-plus people on unemployment in the country. Hazard pay would actually help because a lot of people are the sole breadwinners now in their household especially too because were risking our lives. Bring the unlimited UPT back. That keeps us safe versus coming in, walking around, not knowing whether they have the virus or not. Business is phenomenal for them right now. Even as unrest builds, it has done nothing to knock Amazons share price off the perch, even hitting new record highs. A decent amount of people that I work with have quit. I thought about it. I want to, but I cant. Me and my sister work hard for everything. We were homeless. You know, my biggest fear is going back to that. Amazon is facing questions about its initial response to employees who complained about safety. Two former Amazon employees say they were fired for their activism. Definitely not scared of them. My mother was a Marine, and I was in the Navy. But am I scared of losing what keeps a roof over my head and food in my stomach? Yeah, that Im scared of. We didnt sign up to come in and risk our lives. We didnt sign up to be someones hero. Its a shitty choice. In these uncertain times, I just want to remind you that its still an uncertain time. Dont let these policies expire before the pandemic is over.

Thanks for the flattering commercials, but were about to lose our hazard pay.

As this was unfolding, most of Big Tech, including Amazon, sent white-collar workers home to flatten the curve and fight the pandemic. Tim saw company leadership go to great lengths to make sure this new system was working and actively seek feedback from the remote workers. Christy heard from a warehouse employee who said productivity targets made it difficult for workers to take a break even for hand washing without a mark on their record. Pay for warehouse workers starts at $15 an hour with minimal access to time off ; in May Amazon ended the unpaid leave policy that for a few weeks allowed them to stay home if they had Covid-19 symptoms. The contrast in the treatment of knowledge and warehouse workers couldnt be starker. Equally clear is the cause: One group has power, the other doesnt.

Amazons decision to fire the activists was easy to make in the United States, where Amazon workers have no union and are left to fend for themselves. With no right to paid sick leave or protection from unfair dismissal, American workers are among the most vulnerable in the world to pressure from any employer, not just Amazon.

Union-represented Amazon workers in Spain, Italy, France and Germany initially failed to resolve their concerns through negotiation, but with court action, regulatory intervention and strikes, they got their needs addressed.

Lets look at France: Unions there brought a civil case arguing that Amazon had taken inadequate steps to protect workers from infection risk and that it had sidestepped the unions statutory role. The court ordered Amazon to limit its sales to only essential items, or face harsh penalties until it could reach a safety agreement with the unions. Rather than negotiate, Amazon closed its French operations and appealed. But the appellate court also sided with the workers, who ultimately negotiated a settlement including mandatory union consultation over safety measures, union hiring of external experts to assess the measures effectiveness and a continued increase in workers hourly pay. The news from Europe shows that Amazon can work with unions and get good results.

Both of us want Amazon to share the wealth with workers and stop putting the relentless pursuit of revenue growth ahead of all other concerns. One way or another, this requires putting more power in the hands of workers. Regulation and legislation are part of the solution. But theres no need to wait; power can be taken, not just given. Thats what unions are for.

Amazon is a data-driven company. It should recognize the evidence showing that countries with more collective bargaining have a stronger social fabric and better growth, and are more able to weather economic ups and downs. Businesses with collective bargaining relationships, including Auchan Retail and Carrefour, navigated the Covid-19 crisis with less disruption to their businesses and emerged with their reputations intact and even enhanced.

For its own future and the future of the global economy, Amazon should become more responsive to the women and men whove enriched shareholders and be willing to recognize and bargain with their representatives. When it comes to the rights of its workers, it should be a leader, not a laggard.

Its not just Amazon: The need for more unionization is urgent across Big Tech. Amazon stands out because it combines the extraordinary profit margins of these companies with employing hundreds of thousands of front-line workers. There are fewer of these workers at the other iconic tech companies, but nevertheless their employees also deserve a voice over the issues that matter to them.

The question for Mr. Bezos and the billionaires of the world is: Are they ready to rise to the occasion? Will Big Tech listen to and work with its employees to help the world overcome the worst economic and social crisis in recent history?

Tim Bray is a former vice president at Amazon. Christy Hoffman is the general secretary of UNI Global Union.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WS9-TM51-JB61-100D-00000-00"Amazon hat den Einzelhandel nicht zerstört"2019-08-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:35ZLexisNexis"Amazon hat den Einzelhandel nicht zerstört"

Russell Grandinetti ist seit mehr als 20 Jahren bei Amazon und hat noch die Zeiten als Online-Buchhändler erlebt. Ein Gespräch über Bratpfannen, Supermärkte ohne Kassen, die Marktmacht des Online-Händlers und Jeff Bezos.

Von Gustav Theile

Herr Grandinetti, gibt es Dinge, die nur Deutsche kaufen?

Die Deutschen lieben ihre Bratpfanne. Die ist neben Elektronikprodukten und Spielsachen seit Jahren einer der Bestseller am "Prime Day" in Deutschland. Als wir angefangen haben, kamen die Kunden noch zu uns, weil etwas woanders schwer zu finden war - zum Beispiel eine besondere Nudelsorte, die man im Italien-Urlaub entdeckt hat. Stationäre Läden sind toll, aber die können unmöglich Tausende Nudelsorten bereithalten. Online ist das möglich. Aber wenn ich mir heute unsere meistverkauften Produkte anschaue, dann sind das Dinge, die Menschen jeden Tag benutzen.

Deutschland ist nach den Vereinigten Staaten der zweitwichtigste Absatzmarkt für Amazon. Gibt es dafür einen bestimmten Grund?

Deutsche Kunden nehmen unser Angebot sehr gut an, was uns sehr freut. Die Prime-Mitglieder in Deutschland gehören weltweit zu den aktivsten Nutzern. Ich bin seit mehr als 20 Jahren bei Amazon, und in vielerlei Hinsicht haben sich Bedürfnisse von Kunden nicht geändert: Wir sehen, dass Kunden gute Preise, eine große Auswahl und eine schnelle Lieferung schätzen - und wir arbeiten hart daran, alle drei Dinge zu jeder Zeit zu gewährleisten. Das mögen Kunden überall - auch in Deutschland.

Sie verkaufen ja nicht nur online, sondern haben auch Läden namens Amazon Go. Und dann liefern Sie auch per Drohne. Gibt es Pläne, das auch in Deutschland einzuführen?

Dazu haben wir bisher keine Ankündigung gemacht. Was ich sagen kann: Deutsche stehen sicher nicht lieber in Schlangen an der Kasse als Amerikaner. Schauen Sie sich den kassenlosen Supermarkt Amazon Go in Seattle, New York, San Francisco oder Chicago an - reingehen, auswählen, rauslaufen. Das war's! Bei der Lieferung per Drohne sind viele regulatorische Fragen zu klären. Das verlangt gute Zusammenarbeit mit Regierungen.

Politiker und Marktwächter sind besorgt, Amazon sei zu mächtig geworden. Kürzlich sagte Amerikas Finanzminister, Amazon habe den Einzelhandel zerstört. Stimmen Sie ihm zu?

Nein. Die Fakten sind ziemlich einfach. Der Einzelhandel ist ein sehr großes Geschäft. Amazon macht, global gesehen, weniger als ein Prozent am Handel aus, und in den Vereinigten Staaten stehen wir für weniger als 4 Prozent des Umsatzes. Wir sind nicht einmal der größte Verkäufer in Amerika. Walmart ist etwa doppelt so groß wie wir. Das Gleiche gilt für Deutschland und Großbritannien und anderswo. Das alles widerspricht dieser Aussage. Außerdem erwirtschaften selbständige Verkaufspartner 58 Prozent des gesamten Bruttoumsatzes auf Amazon. Wir helfen ihnen dabei, ihr Geschäft auszubauen.

Warum untersucht die EU-Kommission denn dann, wie Amazon auf Marketplace mit diesen Händlern umgeht?

Ich kann Ihnen versichern, dass wir vollumfänglich mit der Kommission kooperieren und auf die Nachfragen antworten. Ich sage auch: Wir sind sehr stolz darauf, wie wir unseren Verkaufspartnern helfen, mit ihrem Geschäft voranzukommen. Es gibt genug Belege, die zeigen, welchen positiven Einfluss wir auf diese Partner haben: Viele erreichen über uns plötzlich Millionen Kunden weltweit, wachsen, stellen Mitarbeiter ein - allein in Deutschland sind so 120.000 Arbeitsplätze entstanden.

Auch die amerikanischen Wettbewerbshüter untersuchen jetzt die Marktmacht der großen Digitalunternehmen.

Wir sagen seit langem: Gerade bei großen Unternehmen sollte es normal sein, dass man sie unter die Lupe nimmt. So wie wir unser Geschäft betreiben, brauchen uns aber diese Untersuchungen nicht zu beunruhigen, egal wer nachfragt, ob Regierungen oder jemand anderes. Wenn Behörden auf uns zukommen und Fragen stellen, erläutern wir gerne, wie unser Geschäft funktioniert. Ich bin überzeugt: Mit unseren Antworten werden sie zufrieden sein. Wir freuen uns auf diese Gespräche.

Amazon ist also nicht zu groß?

Die Breite sollte nicht mit der Größe verwechselt werden. Wir betreiben ein sehr breites Geschäft: Wir verkaufen nicht nur Produkte, wir bieten auch Cloud-Dienste an, wir sind im Filmgeschäft, es gibt Alexa. Wir sind auch in geographischer Hinsicht breit aufgestellt: in Amerika, Europa, Japan, Indien und in vielen anderen Ländern. Es ist diese Breite, die uns groß erscheinen lässt. In jedem unserer Geschäftsbereiche stehen wir aber in einem intensiven Wettbewerb mit etablierten Mitbewerbern.

Nicht wenige sind ja der Meinung, dass die Größe der Tech-Unternehmen nicht gut ist für Innovationen und das Produktivitätswachstum. Sind die Digitalkonzerne überhaupt noch innovativ oder verlangsamen sie neue Entwicklungen inzwischen?

Ich bin viel unterwegs, überall auf der Welt. Auf diesen Reisen kann ich heute so viel einfacher in Kontakt bleiben mit den Menschen, die ich liebe, etwa indem ich ihnen Bilder schicke, wo immer ich gerade bin. Und ich finde es unglaublich bequem, dass ich durch Tokio mit einer digitalen Karte laufen kann, die ich auch verstehe. Das war früher alles nicht so einfach möglich.

Ist also alles gut mit Big-Tech?

Das heißt nicht, dass es keine Herausforderungen gibt in einer viel vernetzteren Welt. Aber das sollte uns doch nicht generell davon abhalten, Dinge weiter zu verbessern, Neues zu entwickeln und zu automatisieren. Natürlich kann ich verstehen, dass Menschen zuerst an den Arbeitsplatz der Kassierer denken, wenn wir Läden ohne Kasse entwickeln. Das ist eine nachvollziehbare Reaktion. Aber es ist ja nicht so, dass wir in den Läden keine Menschen beschäftigen. Die Mitarbeiter füllen die Regale auf, sie kochen, verpacken. Wir schaffen da viele Arbeitsplätze. Wir machen es dem Kunden nur leichter, den Laden schneller zu verlassen.

Wie hat sich das Unternehmen in dieser Zeit gewandelt?

Viele der Kernelemente sind gleich geblieben, wie wir neue Projekte angehen zum Beispiel: Wir stellen uns vor, wie wir unseren Kunden ein fertiges Produkt erklären werden, wenn wir es rausbringen. Wir gehen also am Anfang des Innovationsprozesses erst mal an sein Ende. Von da arbeiten wir rückwärts. Warum? So stellen wir sicher, dass wir den Kundennutzen nicht aus dem Auge verlieren. Das ist die DNA des Unternehmens. Wir wollen immer unseren Kunden dienen.

Wie hat sich der Gründer Jeff Bezos in dieser Zeit verändert?

Jeffs Neugier war von Anfang an groß und ist geblieben. Kürzlich erst haben wir "Neugierig bleiben und stetig Neues lernen" in unsere Führungsprinzipien aufgenommen. Und Jeff ist oft der wichtigste Anwalt unserer Kunden. Er unterstützt uns, risikofreudig zu sein und neue Dinge zu versuchen und zu entwickeln. Er sorgt dafür, dass Amazon ein guter Ort ist, um Fehler zu machen. Das ist seine Rolle. Das Unternehmen ist in der Zeit größer und erwachsen geworden, das Team um ihn herum auch. Dadurch hat er mehr Zeit, sich genau um das zu kümmern: ein guter Leader sein.

(======================= Linkliste =======================)

Sie sind in New York als Sohn italienischer Einwanderer aufgewachsen und vielleicht der europäischste in der Amazon-Führung. Müssen Sie den anderen manchmal erklären, wie Europa tickt?

Ja, manchmal. Aber das gilt nicht nur für Europa. Für mich ist es eine der größten Herausforderungen, immer wieder neu zu verstehen, was unsere Kunden wollen, vor allem, da viele ja eine andere Sprache sprechen als ich. Auch innerhalb Europas gibt es Unterschiede. Manche erlauben Sonntagslieferungen, andere nicht. Und klar beeinflusst es dich, wenn du überwiegend amerikanische Medien konsumierst. Vergangenes Jahr fragte jemand: Warum schwächelt der Umsatz diese Woche? Und du antwortest: Es ist Fußballweltmeisterschaft.

F.A.Z.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VW5-7N71-JBHT-D21N-00000-00Amazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial Ingredients2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:36ZLexisNexisAmazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial IngredientsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much, and we'll see you in a few minutes.

Good morning, everyone. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, November 13th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets looking to rebound this morning after a serious selloff yesterday. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 95 points.

The market up about a third of a percent on the Dow, half a percent higher on the S&P, and about three quarters and percent higher on the NASDAQ with a 49-point move this morning higher for NASDAQ.

This after broad-based selloff yesterday for stock prices, Apple and Goldman Sachs dragging down the Dow Industrials by better than 600 points at the close.

The S&P 500 was down nearly two percent on the session. As you can see, the NASDAQ the worst performer, down nearly three percent. Apple leading the charge in technology stocks lower yesterday.

Global markets this morning, also seeing a bit of a bounce. The FT-100 is up a fraction, 13 points higher there, 11 points higher on the CAC Quarante in Paris, and the DAX Index in Germany is up 75, that's two-thirds of one percent this morning.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances, as you see there. Best performer in China, up about one percent on the Shanghai Composite.

But the Nikkei Average in Japan down better than two percent overnight.

The picks are in, Amazon will soon call Long Island City, New York, and Crystal City, Virginia home. The details on the company's HQ2 selection with the announcement coming as early as today.

Amazon shares are up this morning, three quarters of one percent.

Raging wildfires in California. This infernos -- the infernos are burning a path of devastation. The death toll now rising to nearly 50 people between these massive fires.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KORY HONEA, SHERIFF, BUTTE COUNTY: I understand that makes this the deadliest fire in the history of the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest and we will take you live to California this morning.

There are new questions facing Boeing this morning. A new report says the jet-maker withheld information on the 737, the same model involved in the deadly Indonesia crash last month.

Boeing Chairman and CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, will join me in a Fox Business exclusive this morning. Stay with us for that exclusive coming up at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning.

Plus Tide detergent unveils new packaging, and it is going viral. The controversy coming up.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle, and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, with us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Cannot wait for that Boeing interview. That'll be fantastic.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that'll be good, because this is -- there are new questions this morning, but at the same time, Boeing has been operating on fire.

I mean, this company is seeing commercial airline business up strongly, the defense business up strongly, and the stock has held up well.

Of course, they are trading down in the month of October. Like the other defense contractors, they had a tough month.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: It'll also be interesting because there are some trade considerations with a company like Boeing. Their rival Airbus in Europe, so it'll be interesting to see what he has to say about that as well.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right. And China is the number one market for the business in terms of new planes and aerospace business.

MCDOWELL: Right. We are at tend of earning season, which Lindsey will get into. Ninety percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported, but we've got retailers this week.

Home Depot just came out with numbers beating on revenue and earnings per share.

BARTIROMO: The numbers are on the screen right now. The estimates call for $2.26 a share. The company is reporting earnings of $2.51 on revenue of -- better than the estimate, which was 26.26 billion and here is the renew estimate coming in better than expected at 23.6 billion.

MCDOWELL: Right. Overall S&P 500 earnings are up almost 29 percent from a year ago. The expectation going into the quarter was 22 percent, so it was a terrific quarter on earnings.

A lot misses on revenue, 40 percent of companies missing on revenue expectations. This was a beat. We get Walmart later this week and some other big retailers like a Macy's, so.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting to see this market performance, Lindsey, in the face of 29 percent profit growth year over year.

BELL: I know. And I think it's still like we always talk about, it's all about the outlook. The outlook was a little bit weaker than expected for many companies as we looked forward to the fourth quarter and into 2019.

There are rising raw material costs, the strong dollar certainly impacting, but you and I was -- we're talking about that in the green room.

And so expectations for growth in 2019 have been coming down. All through this year, we're looking for 10 percent earnings growth in 2019.

Now we're at about eight and a half percent, which is still a very, very good number, but there are still a lot of uncertainties out there with what the fed's going to do, what's going to happen with trade, and then where is the dollar going.

ROSCHELLE: What I -- what I like about the home improvement industry is these are discretionary spends.

BELL: Uh-hmm.

ROSCHELLE: And it tells you something about the consumer, when they're discretionarily spending on things. You don't have to fix up your home, you don't have to do home improvement, and when you do it, that's when the customer feels strong.

So, that may give us an indication of what the rest of the retail season looks like.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's also a really important focus on the consumer.

This week, we will hear --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- as you said, from Walmart and Macy's tomorrow, but Home Depot numbers' better than expected.

As we worry about a growth slowdown, where is the consumer in that growth slowdown?

ROSCHELLE: Well, I mean you know what, I think the consumer remains confident and higher interest rates aren't scaring them away from doing home improvements.

MCDOWELL: Which is good because the home sales this year have been in kind of a slow slide for much of -- much of the year in terms of declines in home sales in consecutive months.

BELL: Yes. Which is why Home Depot's stock hasn't done so well this year. It's down about five percent year to date.

These numbers look to be pretty strong, and we'll have to get into the details. But, you know, the concern is home sales have been weak, interest rates are rising, are investors going -- are peep -- are consumers going to invest in their homes and fixing them up?

BARTIROMO: And you look at a market, like we saw yesterday, where Apple was really the problem.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Down sharply. And you wonder if that's indicator of slowdown. People are worried about unit sales, worried about a slowdown in Apple.

This is the most important product that identifies really what we're talking about in terms of consumer spending.

What did you think about the market selloff yesterday?

MCDOWELL: I think that a lot of this is still a hangover from Apple suddenly announcing that it's not going break out its unit sales because it does look like they're trying to hide something, quite frankly.

And, you know, this was -- they act like that breaking out the unit sales of these products isn't important today. Well -- but -- you know, why was it important then years ago when you -- when you launched the iPhone?

That's number one. I'll just point out that stock is still up almost 15 percent year to date.

So it was roughly immune to what happened to, say, in Amazon in the month of October when Amazon went into a full-blown bear market in that stock.

Apple is still up, it's, you know, pretty -- seeing a pretty sharp decline in the -- so far in November.

But, again, still double-digit gain year to date.

BARTIROMO: And it's really indicative of the story overall, of the worry, the story of this market. We are worried about growth, worried that things will turn down and you see a company like Apple and Home Depot really indicative of the consumer.

BELL: Yes. And I think yesterday's action in Apple really did spook especially tech investors because exactly to your point, Amazon's in bear- market territory. Apple has been the value in the tech sector. And it's been able to hold up and support the group.

And so if growth is slowing there, we -- do we have a bigger problem overall?

MCDOWELL: It was on a report about suppliers.

BELL: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Two --

BELL: Two suppliers.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's another thing, the suppliers made guidance warnings and, you know, you think thank back to what Dan Niles said a couple of weeks ago with the inventory build-up.

I mean he mentioned that Apple had inventories up 89 percent, quarter of a quarter --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in the second quarter and that was an issue because if you've got an economic slowdown and you've got people pulling back in terms of spending, well, what are they going to do?

First, they're going to buy the inventory that they have. Can they actually get rid of all of that inventory?

And if you see China slowing down, is China -- are the Chinese going to buy a phone for a thousand dollars? So, that's why Apple is such an important indicator in terms of what's going on.

MCDOWELL: I will argue also that yesterday was kind of a delayed reaction to that move-up in long-term interest rates last week where you saw the 10- year. Every time -- and we've had this happen several times in the last month or so.

Every time that 10-year treasury yield gets closer to 3.25 percent, because it hit a new -- it was like a seven and a half year-high last week, that rattles investors and the bond market was closed yesterday.

But I think that that is definitely playing into, you know what, if longer- term interest rates are at three and a quarter, three and a half, you know, those earnings, I need to pay a little bit less for those earnings way, way, way out in the future on these big-growth companies.

BELL: Yes, and that's a huge impact on the tech sector.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BELL: Which is supposed to have the best earnings growth in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Let --

BELL: It has had the best growth in the past two years.

BARTIROMO: Let's zero in on this stock market and really what's going on this morning. Joining the conversation, we got the Chairman, President, and CEO of Boeing here in studio this morning, Dennis Muilenburg.

My special guest in the fact of this new report from the Journal on its 737.

Louisiana Congressman and current House Majority Whip, Steve Scalise, joins us with his reaction to the midterm elections and what can get done.

Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane is with us this morning, along with the CEO of the Mayo Clinic, Dr. John Noseworthy back with us as well.

And Florida Congressman-elect, former Green Beret, Lieutenant Colonel Michael Waltz, joining us as well. A lot to talk about. Big guest lineup today, don't miss a moment of it.

And of course we are watching markets this morning after that major selloff yesterday driven by weakness in technology and Apple in familiar.

Joining us now is Fort Pitt Capital Group Partner, Vice President, as well as Senior Portfolio Manager, Kim Forrest. Kim, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

Your reaction to the --

KIM FORREST, VICE PRESIDENT AND SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, FORT PITT CAPITAL GROUP: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the market selloff yesterday and what to do now?

FORREST: Sure. Well, I think you guys covered it ably, you know. All the factors that you cited are just exactly in line with what I saw.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Just to change the conversation, so that's the conversation for the next two years as opposed to what you've been able to do in terms of legislation.

SCALISE: And we've got to be I think a lot better at articulating the things we stand for as conservatives. That's one thing that I think we didn't do well. Just to learn how to do basic things that I couldn't do in those first few weeks after the shooting.

And, you know, I had a lot of -- a lot of support and prayers by the people like you were praying, people all over the country were praying and there were so many miracles that we chronicle in this book and the book we talked about. What my wife Jennifer and I talk about these little miracles that happened along the way. And we also talked about the people who did so many heroic things every step of the way to save not only myself but all the other people that were out there that day.

And then ultimately to help me through the recovery process. And it really is an inspirational book because it could have been a lot different in how it ended. You know, so many cases like this don't end the way it did. This actually has a happy ending and thanks to god, to miracles, and to the support and prayers of so many people. We chronicled it all in the book. Back in the Game and I'm really happy with how it came out.

BARTIROMO: We were so worried. Everybody was worried about you, we -- I mean, it was so serious. Did it change the way you look at things? Did it change the way you approach your job?

SCALISE: Maria, if anything, it sharpened my focus on the things that matter in life and I think I removed a lot of clutter in life. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TRN-CPS1-JBHT-D2V8-00000-00Amazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial Ingredients2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:36ZLexisNexisAmazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial IngredientsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much, and we'll see you in a few minutes.

Good morning, everyone. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, November 13th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets looking to rebound this morning after a serious selloff yesterday. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 95 points.

The market up about a third of a percent on the Dow, half a percent higher on the S&P, and about three quarters and percent higher on the NASDAQ with a 49-point move this morning higher for NASDAQ.

This after broad-based selloff yesterday for stock prices, Apple and Goldman Sachs dragging down the Dow Industrials by better than 600 points at the close.

The S&P 500 was down nearly two percent on the session. As you can see, the NASDAQ the worst performer, down nearly three percent. Apple leading the charge in technology stocks lower yesterday.

Global markets this morning, also seeing a bit of a bounce. The FT-100 is up a fraction, 13 points higher there, 11 points higher on the CAC Quarante in Paris, and the DAX Index in Germany is up 75, that's two-thirds of one percent this morning.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances, as you see there. Best performer in China, up about one percent on the Shanghai Composite.

But the Nikkei Average in Japan down better than two percent overnight.

The picks are in, Amazon will soon call Long Island City, New York, and Crystal City, Virginia home. The details on the company's HQ2 selection with the announcement coming as early as today.

Amazon shares are up this morning, three quarters of one percent.

Raging wildfires in California. This infernos -- the infernos are burning a path of devastation. The death toll now rising to nearly 50 people between these massive fires.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KORY HONEA, SHERIFF, BUTTE COUNTY: I understand that makes this the deadliest fire in the history of the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest and we will take you live to California this morning.

There are new questions facing Boeing this morning. A new report says the jet-maker withheld information on the 737, the same model involved in the deadly Indonesia crash last month.

Boeing Chairman and CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, will join me in a Fox Business exclusive this morning. Stay with us for that exclusive coming up at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning.

Plus Tide detergent unveils new packaging, and it is going viral. The controversy coming up.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle, and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, with us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Cannot wait for that Boeing interview. That'll be fantastic.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that'll be good, because this is -- there are new questions this morning, but at the same time, Boeing has been operating on fire.

I mean, this company is seeing commercial airline business up strongly, the defense business up strongly, and the stock has held up well.

Of course, they are trading down in the month of October. Like the other defense contractors, they had a tough month.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: It'll also be interesting because there are some trade considerations with a company like Boeing. Their rival Airbus in Europe, so it'll be interesting to see what he has to say about that as well.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right. And China is the number one market for the business in terms of new planes and aerospace business.

MCDOWELL: Right. We are at tend of earning season, which Lindsey will get into. Ninety percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported, but we've got retailers this week.

Home Depot just came out with numbers beating on revenue and earnings per share.

BARTIROMO: The numbers are on the screen right now. The estimates call for $2.26 a share. The company is reporting earnings of $2.51 on revenue of -- better than the estimate, which was 26.26 billion and here is the renew estimate coming in better than expected at 23.6 billion.

MCDOWELL: Right. Overall S&P 500 earnings are up almost 29 percent from a year ago. The expectation going into the quarter was 22 percent, so it was a terrific quarter on earnings.

A lot misses on revenue, 40 percent of companies missing on revenue expectations. This was a beat. We get Walmart later this week and some other big retailers like a Macy's, so.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting to see this market performance, Lindsey, in the face of 29 percent profit growth year over year.

BELL: I know. And I think it's still like we always talk about, it's all about the outlook. The outlook was a little bit weaker than expected for many companies as we looked forward to the fourth quarter and into 2019.

There are rising raw material costs, the strong dollar certainly impacting, but you and I was -- we're talking about that in the green room.

And so expectations for growth in 2019 have been coming down. All through this year, we're looking for 10 percent earnings growth in 2019.

Now we're at about eight and a half percent, which is still a very, very good number, but there are still a lot of uncertainties out there with what the fed's going to do, what's going to happen with trade, and then where is the dollar going.

ROSCHELLE: What I -- what I like about the home improvement industry is these are discretionary spends.

BELL: Uh-hmm.

ROSCHELLE: And it tells you something about the consumer, when they're discretionarily spending on things. You don't have to fix up your home, you don't have to do home improvement, and when you do it, that's when the customer feels strong.

So, that may give us an indication of what the rest of the retail season looks like.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's also a really important focus on the consumer.

This week, we will hear --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- as you said, from Walmart and Macy's tomorrow, but Home Depot numbers' better than expected.

As we worry about a growth slowdown, where is the consumer in that growth slowdown?

ROSCHELLE: Well, I mean you know what, I think the consumer remains confident and higher interest rates aren't scaring them away from doing home improvements.

MCDOWELL: Which is good because the home sales this year have been in kind of a slow slide for much of -- much of the year in terms of declines in home sales in consecutive months.

BELL: Yes. Which is why Home Depot's stock hasn't done so well this year. It's down about five percent year to date.

These numbers look to be pretty strong, and we'll have to get into the details. But, you know, the concern is home sales have been weak, interest rates are rising, are investors going -- are peep -- are consumers going to invest in their homes and fixing them up?

BARTIROMO: And you look at a market, like we saw yesterday, where Apple was really the problem.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Down sharply. And you wonder if that's indicator of slowdown. People are worried about unit sales, worried about a slowdown in Apple.

This is the most important product that identifies really what we're talking about in terms of consumer spending.

What did you think about the market selloff yesterday?

MCDOWELL: I think that a lot of this is still a hangover from Apple suddenly announcing that it's not going break out its unit sales because it does look like they're trying to hide something, quite frankly.

And, you know, this was -- they act like that breaking out the unit sales of these products isn't important today. Well -- but -- you know, why was it important then years ago when you -- when you launched the iPhone?

That's number one. I'll just point out that stock is still up almost 15 percent year to date.

So it was roughly immune to what happened to, say, in Amazon in the month of October when Amazon went into a full-blown bear market in that stock.

Apple is still up, it's, you know, pretty -- seeing a pretty sharp decline in the -- so far in November.

But, again, still double-digit gain year to date.

BARTIROMO: And it's really indicative of the story overall, of the worry, the story of this market. We are worried about growth, worried that things will turn down and you see a company like Apple and Home Depot really indicative of the consumer.

BELL: Yes. And I think yesterday's action in Apple really did spook especially tech investors because exactly to your point, Amazon's in bear- market territory. Apple has been the value in the tech sector. And it's been able to hold up and support the group.

And so if growth is slowing there, we -- do we have a bigger problem overall?

MCDOWELL: It was on a report about suppliers.

BELL: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Two --

BELL: Two suppliers.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's another thing, the suppliers made guidance warnings and, you know, you think thank back to what Dan Niles said a couple of weeks ago with the inventory build-up.

I mean he mentioned that Apple had inventories up 89 percent, quarter of a quarter --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in the second quarter and that was an issue because if you've got an economic slowdown and you've got people pulling back in terms of spending, well, what are they going to do?

First, they're going to buy the inventory that they have. Can they actually get rid of all of that inventory?

And if you see China slowing down, is China -- are the Chinese going to buy a phone for a thousand dollars? So, that's why Apple is such an important indicator in terms of what's going on.

MCDOWELL: I will argue also that yesterday was kind of a delayed reaction to that move-up in long-term interest rates last week where you saw the 10- year. Every time -- and we've had this happen several times in the last month or so.

Every time that 10-year treasury yield gets closer to 3.25 percent, because it hit a new -- it was like a seven and a half year-high last week, that rattles investors and the bond market was closed yesterday.

But I think that that is definitely playing into, you know what, if longer- term interest rates are at three and a quarter, three and a half, you know, those earnings, I need to pay a little bit less for those earnings way, way, way out in the future on these big-growth companies.

BELL: Yes, and that's a huge impact on the tech sector.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BELL: Which is supposed to have the best earnings growth in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Let --

BELL: It has had the best growth in the past two years.

BARTIROMO: Let's zero in on this stock market and really what's going on this morning. Joining the conversation, we got the Chairman, President, and CEO of Boeing here in studio this morning, Dennis Muilenburg.

My special guest in the fact of this new report from the Journal on its 737.

Louisiana Congressman and current House Majority Whip, Steve Scalise, joins us with his reaction to the midterm elections and what can get done.

Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane is with us this morning, along with the CEO of the Mayo Clinic, Dr. John Noseworthy back with us as well.

And Florida Congressman-elect, former Green Beret, Lieutenant Colonel Michael Waltz, joining us as well. A lot to talk about. Big guest lineup today, don't miss a moment of it.

And of course we are watching markets this morning after that major selloff yesterday driven by weakness in technology and Apple in familiar.

Joining us now is Fort Pitt Capital Group Partner, Vice President, as well as Senior Portfolio Manager, Kim Forrest. Kim, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

Your reaction to the --

KIM FORREST, VICE PRESIDENT AND SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, FORT PITT CAPITAL GROUP: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the market selloff yesterday and what to do now?

FORREST: Sure. Well, I think you guys covered it ably, you know. All the factors that you cited are just exactly in line with what I saw.

The raise in interest rates, you know, made these higher price stocks a little less desirable.

I do think that Apple may not be something that the -- that is a great thing about -- a great -- I don't know, point of data about how consumers are spending because you did get those great Home Depot numbers.

And I think Apple's its own little issue. But that being beside that, I think today is a tremendous opportunity if you have long-enough time horizon --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORREST: -- to really look and see stocks that you may want to buy right now.

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting you say Apple could have its own issue. I mentioned Dan Niles has been covering this company for years.

FORREST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: AlphaOne Capital Partners, he almost predicted this trouble for Apple and the technology sector a month ago. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Are we looking at fundamentals deteriorating within technology?

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL PARTNERS: I think you absolutely are, and this is exacerbated by the fact that you have a lot of inventory out there.

So, if you pick the biggest company in the world, Apple, for example, they have 89 percent inventory growth year over year in the June quarter that they reported. Their revenues were up 17 percent.

Well, what if the iPhone doesn't sell well? They're going to have to barn that inventory off when we get into the March quarter.

Look at last year, they had one phone priced above a thousand dollars. This holiday season, they have three phones priced above them.

The average selling price, they're trying to boost it by another hundred dollars.

The problem is, if you look at smartphone units overall, this will be the first year in history that smartphone units are down year over year.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Kim, you might say that Apple is its own specific story, but --

FORREST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- doesn't it feed on itself? I mean if you've got a lot of inventory out there in technology and you can't sell it because things are slowing down, that's going to trickle into other retail and other tech.

FORREST: Maybe. We're going to put a big maybe there because here -- here's the issue, I look at tech very differently than a lot of analysts. We're talking about Apple, which is almost solely consumer-oriented tech.

I am really excited about more enterprise or business-related tech because I think as wages are starting to go up, businesses have to once again think about how do I make my employees more productive?

And it's not by watching Netflix, it's not by, you know, participating on Facebook and maybe it's not by buying Apple products.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORREST: But still, semiconductors underlie this whole trend of making people more productive through software and hardware --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORREST: And it's delivered on semiconductors, so that's what I'm kind of throwing out there.

BARTIROMO: I see.

FORREST: And I do think Apple is, you know, an issue in and of itself.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: It is very high-priced products and maybe not everybody, you know, needs to buy a new Apple phone every 18 months --

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: -- like they have in the past.

BARTIROMO: Well, what about Amazon? The Journal is reporting this morning that the company is ready to choose New York City and Northern Virginia as the new homes for Amazon's new headquarters.

Kim, good or bad move on Amazon's part to split the second headquarters? What do you think?

FORREST: Well, I really thought Pittsburgh was the winner here, but, you know, we're going to leave that behind.

But, no, I think it's really smart, especially because it looks like Amazon's going to have to develop its own in-house brands for clothing and what better place than New York City to do that.

The Virginia aspect is kind of interesting, it's close to the government and, you know, I think they need to address a whole lot of maybe regulatory issues.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: So, you know, that makes a whole lot of sense there, too.

BARTIROMO: All right.

MCDOWELL: Oh, just really quickly, I'm sure we'll get to this in the show, but Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has just been elected to Congress, representing part of Queens, is calling in to question Amazon moving into Queens.

The idea of we receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling out and our communities need more investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here that --

Well, we will just talk about that, because that shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the way an economy works.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a misunderstanding of what the whole point in giving tax breaks to companies are.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's the whole point, is to lead to jobs.

FORREST: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Twenty-five thousand jobs.

MCDOWELL: Do you -- do you have a leave -- do you have a leave? Because that gives me a headache. That economic analysis --

BARTIROMO: I have an Advil for you.

MCDOWELL: -- is just --

BARTIROMO: I might have an Advil for you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kim, thank you so much. We will see you soon.

FORREST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We're watching all of the above. Kim Forrest joining us. We'll take a break.

When we come back, wild fires are out of control in California. The multiple blaze is burning across the state, becoming the deadliest in the state history. The very latest coming next.

And then withholding data, new reports suggest Boeing did not share potential problems with flight control systems. It could have played a role in the Lion Air jet crash next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. In Northern California, wild fire becoming the deadliest in state history. Lauren Simonetti with all the details right now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. The monster campfire has now killed at least 42 people in Northern California, hundreds are still unaccounted for. President Trump has approved a major disaster declaration for the Golden State.

In Southern California, that's where you have the Woosley Fire that's destroyed more than 400 homes and businesses. That fire has killed at least two people.

Thousands of structures remain at risk, red-flag warning in effect for L.A. and Ventura counties, and obviously the weather is not helping the situation.

Well, Boeing reportedly withheld information on the Lion Air jet that crashed in Indonesia last month, killing all 189 people on board.

The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Boeing didn't tell airlines about potential hazards in a new flight control feature on their 737 Max.

The problem is that the system can push the plane's nose down so strongly that pilots can't pull it back up. The automated stall prevention system is being investigated as playing a role in the crash.

Shares of Boeing are up a quarter of one percent. And premarket trading, Maria, you will talk to Boeing Chairman, and CEO, President Dennis Muilenburg. That's at 8:30 this morning.

Everybody stay tuned for that that.

Well, fans worldwide are paying tribute to a real superhero. Stan Lee, the father of Spider-Man, The Hulk, Iron Man, and many other memorable comic characters, died yesterday in Los Angeles.

Lee was a legendary Writer and Publisher of Marvel Comics whose creations revolutionized comic books.

His comics were often turned into blockbuster movies, generating billions of dollars worldwide.

Stanley dead at the age of 95. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren. Thank you so much. Coming up next, midterm madness. More inconsistencies in the Florida recount process. They are popping up as the judge tells both sides to ramp down the rhetoric, that and other races still not decided right after this break.

And then a tidy box, this new design for Tide's detergent driving the internet nuts this morning. We will tell you why. Stay with us on that.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching markets this morning after a big selloff yesterday. Futures indicating a rally at the start of trading this morning.

We are looking at a gain of about 145 points on the Dow Industrials, that's two-thirds of one percent after a 600-point selloff yesterday.

The S&P is up 16, and the NASDAQ is up 60 points right now.

I want to turn to the midterm fallout. New oversight, the hours on the senate race has been called. Kyrsten Sinema, becoming the first democrat elected in 30 years.

In Georgia, a judge extending the deadline to certify votes in the governor's race there.

Republican Brian Kemp is ahead by nearly 60,000 that votes right now, but Democrat Stacey Abrams is filing a lawsuit to count rejected ballots.

And then in Florida, ballot drama, the recount is in full swing right now, but large counties are scrambling to meet the deadline of Thursday.

Fox News' Griff Jenkins is in Lauderhill, Florida. He's at the Broward County Office of Elections.

Griff, good morning to you.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning.

You may be watching the markets, but I'm watching ballots being separated in Broward County. Take a look at this. The tabulation room, they still have not begun the recount here.
