They're going to just be about harassing the President, subpoenas and even impeachment.

That's not what the American people wanted. You know, ultimately they're going to have to -- they're going to have to decide which route they go.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Just to change the conversation, so that's the conversation for the next two years as opposed to what you've been able to do in terms of legislation.

SCALISE: And we've got to be I think a lot better at articulating the things we stand for as conservatives. That's one thing that I think we didn't do well. We've got to do a lot better at and we're going to get there but I think there's going to be a sharp contrast now because you're going to see the approach that Nancy Pelosi would take as speaker.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'm glad you mentioned -- a lot of people mentioned the messaging on the Republican side. Let's talk about your book Back in the Game, what role did your recovery have in writing this book? Tell us why you wrote the book.

SCALISE: Well, you know, as you talked about earlier, there were so many people that came together to help me, you know, not only to save my life in those first few hours after the shooting, but to help me get back in the game and essence to be able to learn how to walk again. Just to learn how to do basic things that I couldn't do in those first few weeks after the shooting.

And, you know, I had a lot of -- a lot of support and prayers by the people like you were praying, people all over the country were praying and there were so many miracles that we chronicle in this book and the book we talked about. What my wife Jennifer and I talk about these little miracles that happened along the way. And we also talked about the people who did so many heroic things every step of the way to save not only myself but all the other people that were out there that day.

And then ultimately to help me through the recovery process. And it really is an inspirational book because it could have been a lot different in how it ended. You know, so many cases like this don't end the way it did. This actually has a happy ending and thanks to god, to miracles, and to the support and prayers of so many people. We chronicled it all in the book. Back in the Game and I'm really happy with how it came out.

BARTIROMO: We were so worried. Everybody was worried about you, we -- I mean, it was so serious. Did it change the way you look at things? Did it change the way you approach your job?

SCALISE: Maria, if anything, it sharpened my focus on the things that matter in life and I think I removed a lot of clutter in life. You know, all of us do things every day that some that we want to do, some that you just kind of do because it's a routine and you focus on what's really important, my family, my faith, you know, the work that I do, I love my job. You know, and it illuminated the things that aren't as important and much happier today.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, thank you so much. Thank you for your leadership. So happy you're here.

SCALISE: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So, what happened? Apparently, there were 10 computer -- the computers about the angle of the nose were not accurate and then the plane went down, all 189 people dead. Do you have a sense of what went wrong?

So again, we're going to continue to support the investigation as it proceeds.

BARTIROMO: And was there -- I mean, one of the Boeing officials quoted in The Journal today, one high-ranking Boeing official said that the company had decided against disclosing more details to cockpit cruise due to concerns about inundating average pilots with too much information. MUILENBURG: Now, again, we ensure that we provide all of information that's needed to safely fly our airplanes. BARTIROMO: But was there a new -- well, there are new system that wasn't disclosed to the pilots.

BARTIROMO: Was that information in terms of what to do should something change -- was that information available to the pilots? Did they know how to operate it should the nose be in a different position?

We want to turn to Amazon, congresswoman-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez slamming Amazon's plans to partially bring (INAUDIBLE) headquarters to New York City. Joining me right now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. And Stuart, there was a reason that so many cities across this country were vying for Amazon to come to their city and set up their new headlines. Does she not understand business and economics?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, she does not. I don't think she wants to. There's no pleasing some people, and that's the truth. There's no pleasing a socialist. I'll quote you exactly what she said. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said, Amazon is a-billion-dollar company. The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks is extremely concerning to residents here. Has the company promised to hire in the existing community? What's the quality of jobs? How many are promised? Are these jobs low wage or high wage? Are there benefits? Can people collectively bargain? There's just no satisfying a socialist. They see no benefit to investment, capital infusion and growth. They don't see it. They simply see a big corporation. Give me the money. I just want the money. That's what it's all about.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I'm astonished, actually. I would have thought that when you bring 25,000 new jobs, a couple of billion dollars to your city, it would be universally approved, but apparently not.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but the first thing she does, Dagen, is she complains that Amazon is getting tax breaks (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: And she says Queens City councilman, Jimmy Van Bramer and state Senator Gianaris have also come out against the Amazon deal while Mayor Bill de Blasio says that this could be the single biggest economic development deal in the history of New York City. So, here's a word, Amazon, find another city, I dare you.

VARNEY: For once, I'm on Bill de Blasio's side.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Stuart, I know you'll have more in 10 minutes. We'll see you at the top of the hour, thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Stay with us.

But first, driving innovation, we got a behind-the-scenes look at the journal's technology conference, featuring the CEO of Uber.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The future of technology, the Wall Street Journal's Tech D.Live conference is underway this morning where big names and descending on Laguna Beach, California. Susan Li is there. Susan, good morning.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you, Maria. Yes, we'll be talking all things tech here in Laguna beach. That includes government regulation, innovation, and future partnerships. Now, later on, to the program, will feature a lot of heavyweights, that includes Uber CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, one of the headliners. And then, we have celebrity attendance as well. Gwyneth Paltrow will be holding the evening session along with Kevin Hart, the comedian. Last night, we heard from AT&T's Randall Stephenson who has some interesting things to say about President Trump, about Jim Acosta, Time Warner and CNN, and we also heard from (INAUDIBLE) of Google.

Now, we also caught up with Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's former CEO, billionaire, owner of the L.A. Clips. And I think that the overarching theme her are like going to be so far has been this -- talk about the relationship between the White House and big tech. And whether or not they'll be more regulation in the future of big Silicon Valley names. I asked Steve Ballmer this. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE BALLMER, FORMER CEO, MICROSOFT: I don't think Microsoft has much risk at all right now. We certainly had ours in the past. Amazon will have their own set of issues. The most important thing for anybody running a successful tech company where there's not a clear issue. It's just to continue to do their job well, be responsible. I think Amazon has done a very good job so far.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: Yes. It was an -- a great job, Jeff Bezos has done a great job as Steve Ballmer says. We'll talk more later on today and we have more interviews coming to you and coming on Fox Business from Laguna Beach. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Really good stuff. Susan, thank you. Susan Lee joining us there in Laguna. Coming up, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Back In a Minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Lindsey Bell.

BELL: Look, the markets might be going well, but the bedrock of the country, the consumer is strong and we saw that in Home Depot's numbers and we'll here about that from retailers later this week.

BARTIROMO: Bullish (INAUDIBLE) Mitch?

ROSCHELLE: And I think the markets just need to calm down. You know, sometimes good news is bad news, and bad news is good news. Right now, the market just needs to calm down, calm down.

BARTIROMO: OK. So, it's the stability. Look long term, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: And New York City, I'm going to tweet this. I think the Governor of the New York -- of New York state and the major of New York City, maybe need to do a conference call with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to explain what 25,000 jobs mean in terms of the tax revenue, and how that actually helps fix the New York City subways.

BARTIROMO: And there's a reason that every city in the country wanted the Amazon headquarters.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: They all wanted it.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYV1-DY0W-41NR-00000-00Amazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial Ingredients2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:36ZLexisNexisAmazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial IngredientsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much, and we'll see you in a few minutes.

Good morning, everyone. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, November 13th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets looking to rebound this morning after a serious selloff yesterday. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 95 points.

The market up about a third of a percent on the Dow, half a percent higher on the S&P, and about three quarters and percent higher on the NASDAQ with a 49-point move this morning higher for NASDAQ.

This after broad-based selloff yesterday for stock prices, Apple and Goldman Sachs dragging down the Dow Industrials by better than 600 points at the close.

The S&P 500 was down nearly two percent on the session. As you can see, the NASDAQ the worst performer, down nearly three percent. Apple leading the charge in technology stocks lower yesterday.

Global markets this morning, also seeing a bit of a bounce. The FT-100 is up a fraction, 13 points higher there, 11 points higher on the CAC Quarante in Paris, and the DAX Index in Germany is up 75, that's two-thirds of one percent this morning.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances, as you see there. Best performer in China, up about one percent on the Shanghai Composite.

But the Nikkei Average in Japan down better than two percent overnight.

The picks are in, Amazon will soon call Long Island City, New York, and Crystal City, Virginia home. The details on the company's HQ2 selection with the announcement coming as early as today.

Amazon shares are up this morning, three quarters of one percent.

Raging wildfires in California. This infernos -- the infernos are burning a path of devastation. The death toll now rising to nearly 50 people between these massive fires.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KORY HONEA, SHERIFF, BUTTE COUNTY: I understand that makes this the deadliest fire in the history of the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest and we will take you live to California this morning.

There are new questions facing Boeing this morning. A new report says the jet-maker withheld information on the 737, the same model involved in the deadly Indonesia crash last month.

Boeing Chairman and CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, will join me in a Fox Business exclusive this morning. Stay with us for that exclusive coming up at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning.

Plus Tide detergent unveils new packaging, and it is going viral. The controversy coming up.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle, and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, with us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Cannot wait for that Boeing interview. That'll be fantastic.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that'll be good, because this is -- there are new questions this morning, but at the same time, Boeing has been operating on fire.

I mean, this company is seeing commercial airline business up strongly, the defense business up strongly, and the stock has held up well.

Of course, they are trading down in the month of October. Like the other defense contractors, they had a tough month.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: It'll also be interesting because there are some trade considerations with a company like Boeing. Their rival Airbus in Europe, so it'll be interesting to see what he has to say about that as well.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right. And China is the number one market for the business in terms of new planes and aerospace business.

MCDOWELL: Right. We are at tend of earning season, which Lindsey will get into. Ninety percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported, but we've got retailers this week.

Home Depot just came out with numbers beating on revenue and earnings per share.

BARTIROMO: The numbers are on the screen right now. The estimates call for $2.26 a share. The company is reporting earnings of $2.51 on revenue of -- better than the estimate, which was 26.26 billion and here is the renew estimate coming in better than expected at 23.6 billion.

MCDOWELL: Right. Overall S&P 500 earnings are up almost 29 percent from a year ago. The expectation going into the quarter was 22 percent, so it was a terrific quarter on earnings.

A lot misses on revenue, 40 percent of companies missing on revenue expectations. This was a beat. We get Walmart later this week and some other big retailers like a Macy's, so.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting to see this market performance, Lindsey, in the face of 29 percent profit growth year over year.

BELL: I know. And I think it's still like we always talk about, it's all about the outlook. The outlook was a little bit weaker than expected for many companies as we looked forward to the fourth quarter and into 2019.

There are rising raw material costs, the strong dollar certainly impacting, but you and I was -- we're talking about that in the green room.

And so expectations for growth in 2019 have been coming down. All through this year, we're looking for 10 percent earnings growth in 2019.

Now we're at about eight and a half percent, which is still a very, very good number, but there are still a lot of uncertainties out there with what the fed's going to do, what's going to happen with trade, and then where is the dollar going.

ROSCHELLE: What I -- what I like about the home improvement industry is these are discretionary spends.

BELL: Uh-hmm.

ROSCHELLE: And it tells you something about the consumer, when they're discretionarily spending on things. You don't have to fix up your home, you don't have to do home improvement, and when you do it, that's when the customer feels strong.

So, that may give us an indication of what the rest of the retail season looks like.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's also a really important focus on the consumer.

This week, we will hear --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- as you said, from Walmart and Macy's tomorrow, but Home Depot numbers' better than expected.

As we worry about a growth slowdown, where is the consumer in that growth slowdown?

ROSCHELLE: Well, I mean you know what, I think the consumer remains confident and higher interest rates aren't scaring them away from doing home improvements.

MCDOWELL: Which is good because the home sales this year have been in kind of a slow slide for much of -- much of the year in terms of declines in home sales in consecutive months.

BELL: Yes. Which is why Home Depot's stock hasn't done so well this year. It's down about five percent year to date.

These numbers look to be pretty strong, and we'll have to get into the details. But, you know, the concern is home sales have been weak, interest rates are rising, are investors going -- are peep -- are consumers going to invest in their homes and fixing them up?

BARTIROMO: And you look at a market, like we saw yesterday, where Apple was really the problem.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Down sharply. And you wonder if that's indicator of slowdown. People are worried about unit sales, worried about a slowdown in Apple.

This is the most important product that identifies really what we're talking about in terms of consumer spending.

What did you think about the market selloff yesterday?

MCDOWELL: I think that a lot of this is still a hangover from Apple suddenly announcing that it's not going break out its unit sales because it does look like they're trying to hide something, quite frankly.

And, you know, this was -- they act like that breaking out the unit sales of these products isn't important today. Well -- but -- you know, why was it important then years ago when you -- when you launched the iPhone?

That's number one. I'll just point out that stock is still up almost 15 percent year to date.

So it was roughly immune to what happened to, say, in Amazon in the month of October when Amazon went into a full-blown bear market in that stock.

Apple is still up, it's, you know, pretty -- seeing a pretty sharp decline in the -- so far in November.

But, again, still double-digit gain year to date.

BARTIROMO: And it's really indicative of the story overall, of the worry, the story of this market. We are worried about growth, worried that things will turn down and you see a company like Apple and Home Depot really indicative of the consumer.

BELL: Yes. And I think yesterday's action in Apple really did spook especially tech investors because exactly to your point, Amazon's in bear- market territory. Apple has been the value in the tech sector. And it's been able to hold up and support the group.

And so if growth is slowing there, we -- do we have a bigger problem overall?

MCDOWELL: It was on a report about suppliers.

BELL: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Two --

BELL: Two suppliers.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's another thing, the suppliers made guidance warnings and, you know, you think thank back to what Dan Niles said a couple of weeks ago with the inventory build-up.

I mean he mentioned that Apple had inventories up 89 percent, quarter of a quarter --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in the second quarter and that was an issue because if you've got an economic slowdown and you've got people pulling back in terms of spending, well, what are they going to do?

First, they're going to buy the inventory that they have. Can they actually get rid of all of that inventory?

And if you see China slowing down, is China -- are the Chinese going to buy a phone for a thousand dollars? So, that's why Apple is such an important indicator in terms of what's going on.

MCDOWELL: I will argue also that yesterday was kind of a delayed reaction to that move-up in long-term interest rates last week where you saw the 10- year. Every time -- and we've had this happen several times in the last month or so.

Every time that 10-year treasury yield gets closer to 3.25 percent, because it hit a new -- it was like a seven and a half year-high last week, that rattles investors and the bond market was closed yesterday.

But I think that that is definitely playing into, you know what, if longer- term interest rates are at three and a quarter, three and a half, you know, those earnings, I need to pay a little bit less for those earnings way, way, way out in the future on these big-growth companies.

BELL: Yes, and that's a huge impact on the tech sector.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BELL: Which is supposed to have the best earnings growth in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Let --

BELL: It has had the best growth in the past two years.

BARTIROMO: Let's zero in on this stock market and really what's going on this morning. Joining the conversation, we got the Chairman, President, and CEO of Boeing here in studio this morning, Dennis Muilenburg.

My special guest in the fact of this new report from the Journal on its 737.

Louisiana Congressman and current House Majority Whip, Steve Scalise, joins us with his reaction to the midterm elections and what can get done.

Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane is with us this morning, along with the CEO of the Mayo Clinic, Dr. John Noseworthy back with us as well.

And Florida Congressman-elect, former Green Beret, Lieutenant Colonel Michael Waltz, joining us as well. A lot to talk about. Big guest lineup today, don't miss a moment of it.

And of course we are watching markets this morning after that major selloff yesterday driven by weakness in technology and Apple in familiar.

Joining us now is Fort Pitt Capital Group Partner, Vice President, as well as Senior Portfolio Manager, Kim Forrest. Kim, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

Your reaction to the --

KIM FORREST, VICE PRESIDENT AND SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, FORT PITT CAPITAL GROUP: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the market selloff yesterday and what to do now?

FORREST: Sure. Well, I think you guys covered it ably, you know. All the factors that you cited are just exactly in line with what I saw.

The raise in interest rates, you know, made these higher price stocks a little less desirable.

I do think that Apple may not be something that the -- that is a great thing about -- a great -- I don't know, point of data about how consumers are spending because you did get those great Home Depot numbers.

And I think Apple's its own little issue. But that being beside that, I think today is a tremendous opportunity if you have long-enough time horizon --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORREST: -- to really look and see stocks that you may want to buy right now.

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting you say Apple could have its own issue. I mentioned Dan Niles has been covering this company for years.

FORREST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: AlphaOne Capital Partners, he almost predicted this trouble for Apple and the technology sector a month ago. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Are we looking at fundamentals deteriorating within technology?

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL PARTNERS: I think you absolutely are, and this is exacerbated by the fact that you have a lot of inventory out there.

So, if you pick the biggest company in the world, Apple, for example, they have 89 percent inventory growth year over year in the June quarter that they reported. Their revenues were up 17 percent.

Well, what if the iPhone doesn't sell well? They're going to have to barn that inventory off when we get into the March quarter.

Look at last year, they had one phone priced above a thousand dollars. This holiday season, they have three phones priced above them.

The average selling price, they're trying to boost it by another hundred dollars.

The problem is, if you look at smartphone units overall, this will be the first year in history that smartphone units are down year over year.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Kim, you might say that Apple is its own specific story, but --

FORREST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- doesn't it feed on itself? I mean if you've got a lot of inventory out there in technology and you can't sell it because things are slowing down, that's going to trickle into other retail and other tech.

FORREST: Maybe. We're going to put a big maybe there because here -- here's the issue, I look at tech very differently than a lot of analysts. We're talking about Apple, which is almost solely consumer-oriented tech.

I am really excited about more enterprise or business-related tech because I think as wages are starting to go up, businesses have to once again think about how do I make my employees more productive?

And it's not by watching Netflix, it's not by, you know, participating on Facebook and maybe it's not by buying Apple products.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORREST: But still, semiconductors underlie this whole trend of making people more productive through software and hardware --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORREST: And it's delivered on semiconductors, so that's what I'm kind of throwing out there.

BARTIROMO: I see.

FORREST: And I do think Apple is, you know, an issue in and of itself.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: It is very high-priced products and maybe not everybody, you know, needs to buy a new Apple phone every 18 months --

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: -- like they have in the past.

BARTIROMO: Well, what about Amazon? The Journal is reporting this morning that the company is ready to choose New York City and Northern Virginia as the new homes for Amazon's new headquarters.

Kim, good or bad move on Amazon's part to split the second headquarters? What do you think?

JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. Thousands of families remain evacuated from this area of Southern California where the Woolsey fire has hit so hard. PAUL CHRISTOPHER, HEAD OF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGY, WELLS FARGO INVESTMENT INSTITUTE: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So when you come in today after since a rough day at the office yesterday where the markets were down 600 points on the Dow. What do you do? Are you a buyer or a seller here?

CHRISTOPHER: Yes. We're a buyer. Look, it's -- the markets, it's still worried about growth, it's trying to put in a bottom. You don't have to put in all the chips at once here but people have a lot of cash. Our clients held a lot of cash and we would like for them to put in a little bit here at a time. We think this is the best buying opportunity in U.S. large caps since the November 2016 election.

So don't have to put it all in at once. We're still looking for a bottom but do start to take some positions especially in those growth-oriented sectors.

BELL: So Paul, does that mean you take some positions in the tech, maybe some of the FAANG names that have been beaten up or maybe are in bear market territory right now off of their highs?

CHRISTOPHER: Yes. It's a good question. We've been market weight on information technology. We still think you should be market weight but listen if you haven't had a chance to get into some of these stocks and now you find yourself below market weight. Again this is an opportunity to take yourself back up to that waiting.

MCDOWELL: Paul, it's Dagen McDowell. It seems like the market gets really shaken every time that 10-year yield gets to about only 3-1/4 percent. Realistically how high a yield, a longer term interest rate can stocks handle given a lot of names that are still -- that still look really overvalued?

CHRISTOPHER: Yes. We think that bond yields, the 10-year for instance will go a little bit higher over the next 12 months and that we think that stocks will still be OK with that. This is the same model involved in the deadly Indonesia crash last week. We will speak with Chairman and CEO Dennis Muilenburg next, exclusive coming up right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, November 13th, your top stories right now 8:31 a.m. on the east coast. Futures are indicating a gain at the start of trading this morning. Dow Industrials expected to be up 69 points, that is about a quarter of a percent. S&P 500 is up almost half a percent, and the NASDAQ with a 39-point gain, up two-thirds of one percent. This, after a sharp sell-off yesterday where the Dow lost two percent and the NASDAQ lost almost three percent.

European markets were mixed, the FT-100 is down a fraction, as you can see, but the CAC Quarante and the DAX Index are both positive. Although off of the highest levels of the morning, for sure. Overnight in Asia, mixed performances, take a look, the worst performer was Japan overnight in Asia. The Nikkei Average was down on the session about two percent, as you can see there.

Oil is extending its losing streak this morning. Crude oil under pressure again now 11 days in a row lower, down 1-1/3 percent, below $60.00 a barrel. What is the price of oil selling off tell us about the global economy? We want to look at that, coming up.

All of those stories coming up this morning, but first, our top story this half an hour, new questions this morning for Boeing, The Wall Street journal is reporting that Boeing withheld information on its 737 model, according to safety experts and others. That is the same model involved in the deadly Lion aircrash in Indonesia last month. And joining me right now to discuss that and a lot more in this Fox Business exclusive is the Chairman, President, and CEO of Boeing, Dennis Muilenburg. Dennis, it's good to see you this morning.

DENNIS MUILENBURG, PRESIDENT & CEO, BOEING: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

MUILENBURG: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: And the story in The Journal obviously is very concerning. What can you tell us in terms of what was told to the pilots and the airlines about any new equipment in that 737?

MUILENBURG: Well, Maria, first of all, I think it's important that we all express our sympathies for the loss of Lion Air Flight 610 and certainly, our thoughts go with the families that have been affected. We've been very engaged with the investigative authorities throughout and providing all of the information necessary to make sure we do a full assessment of the situation. And the bottom line here is the 737 max is safe, and safety is a core value for us at Boeing, it always has been, and we ensure that our airplanes are safe. In fact, this airplane went through thousands of hours of tests and evaluation, certification, working with the pilots, and we've been very transparent on providing information and being fully cooperative on the investigative activity.

BARTIROMO: So, what happened? Apparently, there were 10 computer -- the computers about the angle of the nose were not accurate and then the plane went down, all 189 people dead. Do you have a sense of what went wrong?

MUILENBURG: Yes, as the Indonesian authorities have pointed out initially, there were some indications of inaccurate angle attack signal that was being sent to the airplane, and of course, our airplane has the ability to handle that, and we have procedures in place. And we've already issued a couple of additional bulletins to our operators and pilots around the world that point them back to existing flight procedures to handle that kind of condition. So again, we're going to continue to support the investigation as it proceeds.

BARTIROMO: And was there -- I mean, one of the Boeing officials quoted in The Journal today, one high-ranking Boeing official said that the company had decided against disclosing more details to cockpit cruise due to concerns about inundating average pilots with too much information. Was that a decision now that you regret?

MUILENBURG: Now, again, we ensure that we provide all of information that's needed to safely fly our airplanes. Again, this comes as out of thousands of hours of testing and evaluating and simulating, and providing the information that our pilots need to operate our airplanes safely, and we'll continue to do that. As I said, as part of the process here, we've already issued a couple of bulletins to pilots and operators that point them back to existing flight procedures to handle this kind of situation. So, we're going to continue to fully cooperate in the investigation. I think it's really important -- again, the bottomline here, the 737 Max is a very safe airplane and we're very confident in it.

BARTIROMO: But was there a new -- well, there are new system that wasn't disclosed to the pilots.

MUILENBURG: No, there are new systems on the airplanes that are designed to take advantage of the capabilities of the airplane and to provide control capability in high-angle of attack conditions, and those systems operate properly. And again, in certain failure modes, if there's an inaccurate angle attack sensors feeding information to the -- to the airplane, there's a procedure to handle that. And so, again, as part of the investigation process, we're going to make sure we fully understand that. We're going to make sure that we're providing all of the information necessary and appropriate training, and go back to the core value here, is that the airplane safe, we know how to fly it safely, and we're very confident in that.

BARTIROMO: Was that information in terms of what to do should something change -- was that information available to the pilots? Did they know how to operate it should the nose be in a different position?

MUILENBURG: Yes. In fact, that's part of the training manual, it's an existing procedure.

BARTIROMO: I see.

MUILENBURG: So, the bulletin that we put out again last week and over the weekend, pointed to that existing flight procedure.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, obviously, I know that you're answering lots of questions this morning and this week after this horrific crash, and you're going to get more information. What would be the timing on that? When do you expect to hear from the FAA on this?

MUILENBURG: Well, this is an ongoing investigation, so it will take whatever time is necessary to make sure it's done thoroughly. Again, we participate fully in these investigations, we've provided technical assistance, we'll continue to do that until the work is complete. It's very important that we do this in a diligent and thorough manner. Bottomline is we want to ensure safety in the system, and continue to have confidence in the 737 Max.

BARTIROMO: And the 737 has been a cash cow for your business, this is a very important business. There were some headwinds in the supply chain in terms of the 737, which I want to ask you about. And I know over the recent past, you've expanded the business, you've got commercial aerospace, you've got defense, and then you've got services. Tell us how business is right now, because commercial aerospace has been driving the stock obviously for several years right now?

MUILENBURG: Well, aerospace is a tremendous growth business. We look out over the next 10 years as an $8.1 trillion marketplace. Passenger traffic is growing at about six to seven percent per year sustained. The world needs about 43,000 new commercial airplanes over the next 20 years. A part of that is the 737 as we've ramped up to 52 a month, this year, we're producing at 57 a month next year. And we have had some supply chain challenges as you -- as you pointed out, as we've been growing. But we are briskly moving to a recovery. We just announced delivery numbers for October earlier this morning, so we delivered 43 737s in October which is an all-time record for October, and we're continuing to March smartly to our recovery plan, and expect to meet our year-end targets for deliveries. This year, for the first time, we'll deliver more than 800 commercial airplanes. By the end of the decade here, we'll be delivering more than 900 airplanes a year. So, you can see the tremendous growth here in commercial airplanes.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible and I know you got an incredible backlog as well --

MUILENBURG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- which will continue that delivery calendar. One out of four or five planes go to China in terms of your deliveries. Tell us about the importance of the business in China.

MUILENBURG: Yes, China is very important to us. Today, about a third of our 737s go to China, about one-quarter of our overall deliveries. So, if you look at that marketplace around the world, 43,000 new airplanes over the next 20 years, about 7,000 of those are in China. It's the fastest growing market segment right now. China needs that lift capability to serve their economic growth needs, so China is very interested in the healthy aerospace economy.

As you know here in the U.S. as well, there's a big advantage to a healthy aerospace ecosystem. We have about 90 percent of our manufacturing jobs here in the U.S. even though we export about 80 percent of what we build. So when you look at trade deficit versus trade surplus, aerospace is the biggest trade surplus for the U.S., about $80 billion a year. And our business is the biggest piece of that. So, that a mutually-beneficial relationship between the U.S. and China as it applies to trade and the aerospace is very important.

BARTIROMO: So, what happens now with this trade spat that we're having with China then? I mean, have you seen any backlash from the Chinese in terms of your business, given the fact that the President is sitting there waiting to put another 250 billion on exports from China on tariffs and this fight between China and the U.S. intensifies?

MUILENBURG: We've been very engaged in that dialogue, as you know, this is a very important topic to us. We've been talking with the President and the U.S. administration, extensively. They're very aware of the situation and the importance of aerospace. We've also had a very good dialogue with Chinese leadership and our customers in China. And we're encouraged by the dialogue that's going on.

I think you've seen some recent reports that President Trump and President Xi plan to meet around the G20 summit that's coming up. Some productive dialogue going on on the trade front, we think both countries are interested in a mutually successful aerospace ecosystem. It's good for the economies of both countries. And here in the U.S., it's really important to U.S. manufacturing jobs. We have about 13,000 companies in our supply chain here in the U.S. that are supporting that kind of manufacturing growth.

BARTIROMO: Has the air supply chain changed in any way because of your services business? I mean, you're pursuing this more aggressive strategy, does that mean that in time -- in terms of selling a plane to somebody or a business, then you want to maintain that plane as well by using the services there, but are you taking away business from the suppliers?

MUILENBURG: We're actually see this as a grow the pie business. So, something we can do jointly with our suppliers. Services is our biggest single-growth opportunity. When you look at that $8-trillion marketplace, it's the place where we have the biggest opportunity to further grow. And we're bringing capabilities like parts distribution, maintenance, and modifications. New software, digital solutions, training solutions for our customers, doing that jointly with our suppliers.

To date -- year-to-date, our services business has grown 12 percent in a market that's growing about three percent a year. So, it is growing, growing strongly, and by doing this jointly with our supply chain, we can provide better light cycle value for our customers. And that's really the lens we're looking through here, not only how we design and build airplanes, but how do we provide value for our customers for post- production support.

BARTIROMO: This sounds like a natural fit. I mean, the commercial aerospace business has been so strong, and walk us through that for a moment because most people don't understand the number of people who've never been on an airplane.

MUILENBURG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: The number of people who are perhaps in Asia who are wanting to travel, this is a big opportunity for you. So, this is also an economic growth story.

MUILENBURG: It is. And, Maria, you bring up a really great point. As I said earlier, traffic is growing -- passenger traffic at about six to seven percent a year completely outstripping GDP. And some of the things that are driving that is the upcoming middle class that for the first time ever, is able to travel. So, we have this unique combination of backlogs, seven years of backlog. And every year in Asia alone, 150 million people fly for the first time. Less than -- less than 20 percent.

BARTIROMO: It's amazing.

MUILENBURG: Less than 20 percent of the world's population has ever taken a single flight. So, think about the growth opportunity that's still ahead of us, and we're feeding right into that with our design and productions.

BARTIROMO: But here we have worries in the market, down 600 points yesterday, worries from economic worries that things are going to slow down.

MUILENBURG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So, where are we on that in your view? You've got interest rates rising obviously when a company or country buys a plane, or several planes, they are in many parts doing it by borrowing, their borrowing costs are going up with interest rates. How much of a headwind will that be for you?

MUILENBURG: We're not seeing it affect our business. Again, we have a much longer term view. Today, we have a backlog of almost 5800 commercial airplanes if you think of that in terms of production volume, it's about seven years of backlog.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MUILENBURG: So, this gives us the opportunity to think long term in terms of capital investment, innovation investment. And while we pay attention to things like interest rates and the financial markets, it's not something that's really affecting near-term buying behavior. You know, today, we're selling 737 Maxes, filling our production skyline out in 2023 and beyond. So, we have a much longer term perspective. Aerospace is a strong long- term growing business. It's not -- it's no longer a cyclical business. This is a long term sustained growth business.

BARTIROMO: But the competition is fierce. I mean, airbus -- can airbus sell to European countries and companies with no tariffs? So, are you disadvantaged by the tariff situation given the fact that a European jetmaker Airbus can do it a lot cheaper?

MUILENBURG: Well, something we're paying close attention to. To date, we haven't been affected materially by the tariffs. Things that have affected steel and aluminum pricing. We source 90 percent of our aluminum here in the U.S. so it hasn't been a dramatic effect on us, but it's something we're paying a close attention to. The bottom line is it's a very competitive marketplace because it's a very attractive marketplace. Now, we have to continue to invest, to compete. We have to continue to invest to innovate. Tax reform, for example, in the U.S. has been something that has really helped us gain a level-playing field globally so that we can compete and win.

BARTIROMO: How can you grow the defense business at this point? A lot of worries that defense spending needs to either be capped or cut, given the trillion-dollar deficits we're talking about every day and the debt of 21 trillion.

MUILENBURG: Yes, we see the defense budget here in the U.S. sustained, and if you look back a couple of years when we were in the middle of sequestration. We feel like we're in a stronger budget position now on both sides of the aisle. So, we look to the U.S. defense budget to remain strong. But we also see growth around the world. Today, about a third of our defense backlog is outside the U.S. So, again, this is a very global business, and there's a lot of defense growth opportunities outside of the U.S., and I think the thing that's unique about Boeing is when we think about growth, we look across commercial defense and services. We're really the only aerospace company that can bring great big critical mass to all three of those sectors.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching that. Dennis, it's great to have you on the program.

MUILENBURG: Likewise. Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Dennis Muilenburg, ceo at Boeing. We will be right back. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5TRN-CPS1-JBHT-D2TD-00000-00Amazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial Ingredients2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:10:36ZLexisNexisAmazon HQ1 Picks Are In; C.A. Wildfires Kill 44 People; Florida Ballot Drama; New Satellite Images Show North Korea Not Halting Their Nuclear Program; Trump Mounts Pressure on Saudis after Plans to Cut Oil Production; Reports: President Trump Looking to Remove DHC Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen; El Chapo Trial To Begin; Zuckerberg Facing Contempt; Petco To Stop Selling Food And Treats Containing Artificial IngredientsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. Thank you so much, and we'll see you in a few minutes.

Good morning, everyone. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, November 13th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets looking to rebound this morning after a serious selloff yesterday. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 95 points.

The market up about a third of a percent on the Dow, half a percent higher on the S&P, and about three quarters and percent higher on the NASDAQ with a 49-point move this morning higher for NASDAQ.

This after broad-based selloff yesterday for stock prices, Apple and Goldman Sachs dragging down the Dow Industrials by better than 600 points at the close.

The S&P 500 was down nearly two percent on the session. As you can see, the NASDAQ the worst performer, down nearly three percent. Apple leading the charge in technology stocks lower yesterday.

Global markets this morning, also seeing a bit of a bounce. The FT-100 is up a fraction, 13 points higher there, 11 points higher on the CAC Quarante in Paris, and the DAX Index in Germany is up 75, that's two-thirds of one percent this morning.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances, as you see there. Best performer in China, up about one percent on the Shanghai Composite.

But the Nikkei Average in Japan down better than two percent overnight.

The picks are in, Amazon will soon call Long Island City, New York, and Crystal City, Virginia home. The details on the company's HQ2 selection with the announcement coming as early as today.

Amazon shares are up this morning, three quarters of one percent.

Raging wildfires in California. This infernos -- the infernos are burning a path of devastation. The death toll now rising to nearly 50 people between these massive fires.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KORY HONEA, SHERIFF, BUTTE COUNTY: I understand that makes this the deadliest fire in the history of the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest and we will take you live to California this morning.

There are new questions facing Boeing this morning. A new report says the jet-maker withheld information on the 737, the same model involved in the deadly Indonesia crash last month.

Boeing Chairman and CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, will join me in a Fox Business exclusive this morning. Stay with us for that exclusive coming up at 8:30 a.m. Eastern this morning.

Plus Tide detergent unveils new packaging, and it is going viral. The controversy coming up.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner Mitch Roschelle, and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell, with us this morning. Good to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Cannot wait for that Boeing interview. That'll be fantastic.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that'll be good, because this is -- there are new questions this morning, but at the same time, Boeing has been operating on fire.

I mean, this company is seeing commercial airline business up strongly, the defense business up strongly, and the stock has held up well.

Of course, they are trading down in the month of October. Like the other defense contractors, they had a tough month.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: It'll also be interesting because there are some trade considerations with a company like Boeing. Their rival Airbus in Europe, so it'll be interesting to see what he has to say about that as well.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right. And China is the number one market for the business in terms of new planes and aerospace business.

MCDOWELL: Right. We are at tend of earning season, which Lindsey will get into. Ninety percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported, but we've got retailers this week.

Home Depot just came out with numbers beating on revenue and earnings per share.

BARTIROMO: The numbers are on the screen right now. The estimates call for $2.26 a share. The company is reporting earnings of $2.51 on revenue of -- better than the estimate, which was 26.26 billion and here is the renew estimate coming in better than expected at 23.6 billion.

MCDOWELL: Right. Overall S&P 500 earnings are up almost 29 percent from a year ago. The expectation going into the quarter was 22 percent, so it was a terrific quarter on earnings.

A lot misses on revenue, 40 percent of companies missing on revenue expectations. This was a beat. We get Walmart later this week and some other big retailers like a Macy's, so.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting to see this market performance, Lindsey, in the face of 29 percent profit growth year over year.

BELL: I know. And I think it's still like we always talk about, it's all about the outlook. The outlook was a little bit weaker than expected for many companies as we looked forward to the fourth quarter and into 2019.

There are rising raw material costs, the strong dollar certainly impacting, but you and I was -- we're talking about that in the green room.

And so expectations for growth in 2019 have been coming down. All through this year, we're looking for 10 percent earnings growth in 2019.

Now we're at about eight and a half percent, which is still a very, very good number, but there are still a lot of uncertainties out there with what the fed's going to do, what's going to happen with trade, and then where is the dollar going.

ROSCHELLE: What I -- what I like about the home improvement industry is these are discretionary spends.

BELL: Uh-hmm.

ROSCHELLE: And it tells you something about the consumer, when they're discretionarily spending on things. You don't have to fix up your home, you don't have to do home improvement, and when you do it, that's when the customer feels strong.

So, that may give us an indication of what the rest of the retail season looks like.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it's also a really important focus on the consumer.

This week, we will hear --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- as you said, from Walmart and Macy's tomorrow, but Home Depot numbers' better than expected.

As we worry about a growth slowdown, where is the consumer in that growth slowdown?

ROSCHELLE: Well, I mean you know what, I think the consumer remains confident and higher interest rates aren't scaring them away from doing home improvements.

MCDOWELL: Which is good because the home sales this year have been in kind of a slow slide for much of -- much of the year in terms of declines in home sales in consecutive months.

BELL: Yes. Which is why Home Depot's stock hasn't done so well this year. It's down about five percent year to date.

These numbers look to be pretty strong, and we'll have to get into the details. But, you know, the concern is home sales have been weak, interest rates are rising, are investors going -- are peep -- are consumers going to invest in their homes and fixing them up?

BARTIROMO: And you look at a market, like we saw yesterday, where Apple was really the problem.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Down sharply. And you wonder if that's indicator of slowdown. People are worried about unit sales, worried about a slowdown in Apple.

This is the most important product that identifies really what we're talking about in terms of consumer spending.

What did you think about the market selloff yesterday?

MCDOWELL: I think that a lot of this is still a hangover from Apple suddenly announcing that it's not going break out its unit sales because it does look like they're trying to hide something, quite frankly.

And, you know, this was -- they act like that breaking out the unit sales of these products isn't important today. Well -- but -- you know, why was it important then years ago when you -- when you launched the iPhone?

That's number one. I'll just point out that stock is still up almost 15 percent year to date.

So it was roughly immune to what happened to, say, in Amazon in the month of October when Amazon went into a full-blown bear market in that stock.

Apple is still up, it's, you know, pretty -- seeing a pretty sharp decline in the -- so far in November.

But, again, still double-digit gain year to date.

BARTIROMO: And it's really indicative of the story overall, of the worry, the story of this market. We are worried about growth, worried that things will turn down and you see a company like Apple and Home Depot really indicative of the consumer.

BELL: Yes. And I think yesterday's action in Apple really did spook especially tech investors because exactly to your point, Amazon's in bear- market territory. Apple has been the value in the tech sector. And it's been able to hold up and support the group.

And so if growth is slowing there, we -- do we have a bigger problem overall?

MCDOWELL: It was on a report about suppliers.

BELL: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Two --

BELL: Two suppliers.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's another thing, the suppliers made guidance warnings and, you know, you think thank back to what Dan Niles said a couple of weeks ago with the inventory build-up.

I mean he mentioned that Apple had inventories up 89 percent, quarter of a quarter --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- in the second quarter and that was an issue because if you've got an economic slowdown and you've got people pulling back in terms of spending, well, what are they going to do?

First, they're going to buy the inventory that they have. Can they actually get rid of all of that inventory?

And if you see China slowing down, is China -- are the Chinese going to buy a phone for a thousand dollars? So, that's why Apple is such an important indicator in terms of what's going on.

MCDOWELL: I will argue also that yesterday was kind of a delayed reaction to that move-up in long-term interest rates last week where you saw the 10- year. Every time -- and we've had this happen several times in the last month or so.

Every time that 10-year treasury yield gets closer to 3.25 percent, because it hit a new -- it was like a seven and a half year-high last week, that rattles investors and the bond market was closed yesterday.

But I think that that is definitely playing into, you know what, if longer- term interest rates are at three and a quarter, three and a half, you know, those earnings, I need to pay a little bit less for those earnings way, way, way out in the future on these big-growth companies.

BELL: Yes, and that's a huge impact on the tech sector.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BELL: Which is supposed to have the best earnings growth in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Let --

BELL: It has had the best growth in the past two years.

BARTIROMO: Let's zero in on this stock market and really what's going on this morning. Joining the conversation, we got the Chairman, President, and CEO of Boeing here in studio this morning, Dennis Muilenburg.

My special guest in the fact of this new report from the Journal on its 737.

Louisiana Congressman and current House Majority Whip, Steve Scalise, joins us with his reaction to the midterm elections and what can get done.

Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst and retired four-star general, Jack Keane is with us this morning, along with the CEO of the Mayo Clinic, Dr. John Noseworthy back with us as well.

And Florida Congressman-elect, former Green Beret, Lieutenant Colonel Michael Waltz, joining us as well. A lot to talk about. Big guest lineup today, don't miss a moment of it.

And of course we are watching markets this morning after that major selloff yesterday driven by weakness in technology and Apple in familiar.

Joining us now is Fort Pitt Capital Group Partner, Vice President, as well as Senior Portfolio Manager, Kim Forrest. Kim, good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

Your reaction to the --

KIM FORREST, VICE PRESIDENT AND SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, FORT PITT CAPITAL GROUP: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the market selloff yesterday and what to do now?

FORREST: Sure. Well, I think you guys covered it ably, you know. All the factors that you cited are just exactly in line with what I saw.

The raise in interest rates, you know, made these higher price stocks a little less desirable.

I do think that Apple may not be something that the -- that is a great thing about -- a great -- I don't know, point of data about how consumers are spending because you did get those great Home Depot numbers.

And I think Apple's its own little issue. But that being beside that, I think today is a tremendous opportunity if you have long-enough time horizon --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORREST: -- to really look and see stocks that you may want to buy right now.

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting you say Apple could have its own issue. I mentioned Dan Niles has been covering this company for years.

FORREST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: AlphaOne Capital Partners, he almost predicted this trouble for Apple and the technology sector a month ago. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Are we looking at fundamentals deteriorating within technology?

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL PARTNERS: I think you absolutely are, and this is exacerbated by the fact that you have a lot of inventory out there.

So, if you pick the biggest company in the world, Apple, for example, they have 89 percent inventory growth year over year in the June quarter that they reported. Their revenues were up 17 percent.

Well, what if the iPhone doesn't sell well? They're going to have to barn that inventory off when we get into the March quarter.

Look at last year, they had one phone priced above a thousand dollars. This holiday season, they have three phones priced above them.

The average selling price, they're trying to boost it by another hundred dollars.

The problem is, if you look at smartphone units overall, this will be the first year in history that smartphone units are down year over year.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Kim, you might say that Apple is its own specific story, but --

FORREST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- doesn't it feed on itself? I mean if you've got a lot of inventory out there in technology and you can't sell it because things are slowing down, that's going to trickle into other retail and other tech.

FORREST: Maybe. We're going to put a big maybe there because here -- here's the issue, I look at tech very differently than a lot of analysts. We're talking about Apple, which is almost solely consumer-oriented tech.

I am really excited about more enterprise or business-related tech because I think as wages are starting to go up, businesses have to once again think about how do I make my employees more productive?

And it's not by watching Netflix, it's not by, you know, participating on Facebook and maybe it's not by buying Apple products.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORREST: But still, semiconductors underlie this whole trend of making people more productive through software and hardware --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

FORREST: And it's delivered on semiconductors, so that's what I'm kind of throwing out there.

BARTIROMO: I see.

FORREST: And I do think Apple is, you know, an issue in and of itself.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: It is very high-priced products and maybe not everybody, you know, needs to buy a new Apple phone every 18 months --

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: -- like they have in the past.

BARTIROMO: Well, what about Amazon? The Journal is reporting this morning that the company is ready to choose New York City and Northern Virginia as the new homes for Amazon's new headquarters.

Kim, good or bad move on Amazon's part to split the second headquarters? What do you think?

FORREST: Well, I really thought Pittsburgh was the winner here, but, you know, we're going to leave that behind.

But, no, I think it's really smart, especially because it looks like Amazon's going to have to develop its own in-house brands for clothing and what better place than New York City to do that.

The Virginia aspect is kind of interesting, it's close to the government and, you know, I think they need to address a whole lot of maybe regulatory issues.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FORREST: So, you know, that makes a whole lot of sense there, too.

BARTIROMO: All right.

MCDOWELL: Oh, just really quickly, I'm sure we'll get to this in the show, but Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has just been elected to Congress, representing part of Queens, is calling in to question Amazon moving into Queens.

The idea of we receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling out and our communities need more investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here that --

Well, we will just talk about that, because that shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the way an economy works.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a misunderstanding of what the whole point in giving tax breaks to companies are.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's the whole point, is to lead to jobs.

FORREST: Right.

ROSCHELLE: Twenty-five thousand jobs.

MCDOWELL: Do you -- do you have a leave -- do you have a leave? Because that gives me a headache. That economic analysis --

BARTIROMO: I have an Advil for you.

MCDOWELL: -- is just --

BARTIROMO: I might have an Advil for you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kim, thank you so much. We will see you soon.

FORREST: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We're watching all of the above. Kim Forrest joining us. We'll take a break.

When we come back, wild fires are out of control in California. The multiple blaze is burning across the state, becoming the deadliest in the state history. The very latest coming next.

And then withholding data, new reports suggest Boeing did not share potential problems with flight control systems. It could have played a role in the Lion Air jet crash next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. In Northern California, wild fire becoming the deadliest in state history. Lauren Simonetti with all the details right now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. The monster campfire has now killed at least 42 people in Northern California, hundreds are still unaccounted for. President Trump has approved a major disaster declaration for the Golden State.

In Southern California, that's where you have the Woosley Fire that's destroyed more than 400 homes and businesses. That fire has killed at least two people.

Thousands of structures remain at risk, red-flag warning in effect for L.A. and Ventura counties, and obviously the weather is not helping the situation.

Well, Boeing reportedly withheld information on the Lion Air jet that crashed in Indonesia last month, killing all 189 people on board.

The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Boeing didn't tell airlines about potential hazards in a new flight control feature on their 737 Max.

The problem is that the system can push the plane's nose down so strongly that pilots can't pull it back up. The automated stall prevention system is being investigated as playing a role in the crash.

Shares of Boeing are up a quarter of one percent. And premarket trading, Maria, you will talk to Boeing Chairman, and CEO, President Dennis Muilenburg. That's at 8:30 this morning.

Everybody stay tuned for that that.

Well, fans worldwide are paying tribute to a real superhero. Stan Lee, the father of Spider-Man, The Hulk, Iron Man, and many other memorable comic characters, died yesterday in Los Angeles.

Lee was a legendary Writer and Publisher of Marvel Comics whose creations revolutionized comic books.

His comics were often turned into blockbuster movies, generating billions of dollars worldwide.

Stanley dead at the age of 95. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren. Thank you so much. Coming up next, midterm madness. More inconsistencies in the Florida recount process. They are popping up as the judge tells both sides to ramp down the rhetoric, that and other races still not decided right after this break.

And then a tidy box, this new design for Tide's detergent driving the internet nuts this morning. We will tell you why. Stay with us on that.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching markets this morning after a big selloff yesterday. Futures indicating a rally at the start of trading this morning.

We are looking at a gain of about 145 points on the Dow Industrials, that's two-thirds of one percent after a 600-point selloff yesterday.

The S&P is up 16, and the NASDAQ is up 60 points right now.

I want to turn to the midterm fallout. New oversight, the hours on the senate race has been called. Kyrsten Sinema, becoming the first democrat elected in 30 years.

In Georgia, a judge extending the deadline to certify votes in the governor's race there.

Republican Brian Kemp is ahead by nearly 60,000 that votes right now, but Democrat Stacey Abrams is filing a lawsuit to count rejected ballots.

And then in Florida, ballot drama, the recount is in full swing right now, but large counties are scrambling to meet the deadline of Thursday.

Fox News' Griff Jenkins is in Lauderhill, Florida. He's at the Broward County Office of Elections.

Griff, good morning to you.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning.

You may be watching the markets, but I'm watching ballots being separated in Broward County. Take a look at this. The tabulation room, they still have not begun the recount here.

Now in 65 of Florida's 67 counties, they are either halfway done or even more from the recount being done, but here in Palm Beach County, they're far from it. What they have to do is finish separating page one.

Then they'll likely do a calibration of the machines and begin the actual official tabulation recount. That isn't expected any time before about 9:00 a.m. here so it's quite an issue as they race towards the Thursday deadline to get those numbers in.

But we were surprised, Maria, yesterday when the Election Supervisor here, Dr. Brenda Snipes, came out, talked to the media, and addressed allegations that she has made major mistakes this election, take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRENDA SNIPES, SUPERVISOR OF ELECTIONS, BROWARD COUNTY: The lawsuits, as they are written, certainly cast dispersions on my character.

I've have worked here for about 15 years and I have to say this is the first time that this office or I have been under such attacks, so if we make mistakes, we own mistakes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: Then the stunning development, FormerFlorida Governor, Jeb Bush, tweeting that he believes Snipes failed to comply with the law in multiple counts and called for her removal.

Jeb was the one that appointed her in 2003 to replace the previous supervisor who had to be removed for similar problems.

Meanwhile, on the national level, Senator Nelson and Governor Scott trading nasty barbs, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BILL NELSON (D), CALIFORNIA: Scott cannot oversee this process in a fair and impartial way, and thus he should remove himself from any role in the recount process.

GOV. RICK SCOTT (R), FLORIDA: Our goal is that we follow the law. We know Brenda Snipes mixed illegal ballots with legal ballots. We know they've not let party officials in, the courts have said follow the law.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: If they do indeed get this recount started and meet that Thursday deadline here in Broward County, Maria, lawyers tell me that they expect the margin of error to be under that .25 percent and will be headed for a hand recount after Thursday. Maria.
